metadata.h1: Why we run datathons for dementia

all_paragraphs: Dementia is one of our society’s most urgent health problems and one where data scientists can contribute so much. The current frontiers in the scientific understanding — how does it begin in the brain? What are the earliest signs? How can we treat it early? — are notoriously difficult to unpick when there are no visible symptoms until late on in the disease development. If you’ve never worked with real-world health data before, the complexity of the variables and how to access these data — let alone knowing enough to form your research question — can feel like an un-scalable challenge. Dementia is much too big a problem to leave just to the neurologists. We need data scientists of all backgrounds working on it and that’s why we set up our datathon series.
How do the dementia datathons work?

Our datathons are essentially ‘hackathons’ but with additional structure and learning opportunities. Researchers of all stripes come along for three days. In previous datathons we’ve had a researcher with an astrophysics background, a researcher with a genetics background and researchers with pure maths backgrounds too. They all got an introduction to the population health cohort datasets we work with, we form teams, and then everyone logs in to the virtual analysis environment in the DPUK Data Portal. The analysis environment is a virtual desktop (eg 32GB, 8 CPUs with preinstalled software including R and Python). It’s completely secure — it’s impossible for any of the participants to download the raw data files or corrupt original files by mistake.

One important difference from a typical hackathon is that there’s no competitive element. Datathons are about team working, however what data researcher doesn’t want to get a publication if they can? This is an opportunity to kick-start that paper and the lead scientists present are on hand to help attendees to do just that.

We run our datathons in partnership with the Alan Turing Institute and Alzheimer’s Research UK and one of the most important things we’ve learnt is that the introduction to the data and the field is really important. Not all the participants have a background in dementia research — indeed, fresh ideas are what we want. We’ve found that attendees have enjoyed working with subject experts — that’s where we find that exciting sparks of great ideas can happen. All our datathons so far have been led by researchers with a joint data-psychology background, and that’s something we’ll continue with in the next series.

We know that the real-world cohort data we need data scientists to work on is messy and complex. Data scientists might well have had experience of working with large volumes of data but not necessarily the complexity of the variables we need to look at. It’s necessary that we work with data like this but we’ve learnt that it’s very helpful to give datathon attendees a good overview of the datasets we work with — not only data dictionaries but also introductions to the history of the data collection, how it’s coded, what may be missing, the folder structure.

We’ve found that attendees learn from each other. There are so many techniques in data science — it’s exciting to see what happens when people’s different expertise comes together. We’re definitely going to keep encouraging researchers from a variety of backgrounds to attend.

And the upshot? Our pioneer datathoners loved it! There was a lot of enthusiasm for the format in the room, and a real mixing of minds from people who wouldn’t normally have worked together before. We’re seeing previous attendees building on the work they started in the datathon into full research proposals and many plan to come back.
Your home for data science. A Medium publication sharing concepts, ideas and codes.
Senior data and science manager for Dementias Platform UK (DPUK). DPUK is creating the world’s richest source of people data for use in dementia research.
